description.narrative: Bujagali Energy Limited (BEL or the Company) owns and operates the 250 MW hydro power project (the Project) on Dumbbell Island, on the Nile River 8 km north of Jinja, Uganda. The Project was commissioned in 2012 and sells its entire output under a 30-year power purchase agreement with Uganda Electricity Transmission Company Limited (UETCL). The Project is an important source of power for the country as it generated c.44% of Ugandas electricity in 2016. IFCs proposed debt investment of up to $100 million for its own account, out of a total package of up to approximately $500 million, will be utilized by the Company to refinance its existing debt. The refinancing will lengthen the tenor of the Companys existing loans and therefore reduce the amount of annual debt service and, in turn, lower the Projects tariff under the power purchase agreement with UETCL. This will make the electricity in Uganda more affordable and is expected to support the governments increasing electricity access agenda in the country. The proposed investment is not expected to result in any change to the Projects physical or operational footprint or to its current power transmission arrangements.

In recent years, the Government of Uganda ("GOU") has shown a strong focus on the country's rapid industrialization by catalyzing growth in the manufacturing sector. The spillover effects of a country's strong manufacturing sector cannot be overstated: they include growth in productivity, the potential for diversification into a variety of economic activities, increased value addition vis-Ã -vis other primary sectors and creation of new employment opportunities. In support of this objective, the GOU is implementing a three-pronged approach for the electricity sector of (i) lowering electricity tariffs, (ii) increasing generation; and (iii) increasing electricity access. These are critical steps in increasing the competitiveness of the electricity sector, and by extension the manufacturing sector, compared to other countries in the East Africa region. In this context, the proposed transaction is key in making electricity generation more affordable, given that the Project contributed c.44% of the country's energy generation and c.65% of its 2016 generation costs, as disclosed by the Electricity Regulatory Agency (ERA). Reducing the cost of generation is the first step towards reducing tariffs for end users and catalyzing economic growth. Furthermore, the resulting tariff reduction is expected to improve the power sector sustainability and is in line with the GOU's increasing electricity access agenda. To this end, the GOU is also considering several incentive programs to increase demand for electricity and generally boost economic activity in the country.
